message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including right-sided back pain radiating to the groin, nausea, and pain with urination, suggest nephrolithiasis. The costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side also supports this diagnosis. The negative urine findings for protein, RBC casts, and WBC casts, but presence of RBCs and WBCs, suggest an obstructive process rather than infection, ruling out pyelonephritis. Cholecystitis and pelvic inflammatory disease are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe right-sided back pain radiating to the right groin, nausea, and pain with urination. The laboratory findings show RBCs in the urine, which suggests nephrolithiasis (kidney stone). Cholecystitis would present with right upper quadrant pain and fever. Pelvic inflammatory disease would present with pelvic pain and discharge. Pyelonephritis would present with fever and flank pain, but the presence of RBCs in the urine makes nephrolithiasis a more likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including severe right-sided back pain that radiates to the right groin, as well as nausea and pain with urination, suggest nephrolithiasis (a kidney stone). The presence of RBCs in the urine also supports this diagnosis. Cholecystitis would present with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, while pelvic inflammatory disease would present with lower abdominal pain. Pyelonephritis would likely present with a fever and more significant changes in laboratory studies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe right-sided back pain radiating to the right groin and pain with urination, which are symptoms of nephrolithiasis or kidney stones. The laboratory study shows the presence of RBCs and WBCs in the urine, further supporting this diagnosis. Cholecystitis typically presents with pain in the upper right abdomen and fever, which the patient does not have. Pelvic inflammatory disease typically presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. Pyelonephritis can present with similar symptoms but is less likely given the absence of fever and other signs of systemic infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant, has severe right-sided back pain radiating to the right groin, and pain with urination, all of which suggest nephrolithiasis. The laboratory results also show RBC in the urine, which is a common finding in nephrolithiasis. Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, while pelvic inflammatory disease may present with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge. Pyelonephritis may present with back pain and fever, but the absence of fever makes this less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The severe right-sided back pain that radiates to the right groin, along with nausea and pain with urination, suggests nephrolithiasis. Costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side points to renal involvement. The urinalysis shows RBC and no WBC casts, which is consistent with nephrolithiasis. None of the other options fit with the symptoms and the urinalysis results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including severe right-sided back pain radiating to the right groin, nausea, and pain with urination, are characteristic of nephrolithiasis. The presence of RBCs in the urine suggests the presence of a stone, and the absence of WBC casts and proteinuria make pyelonephritis less likely. Cholecystitis and pelvic inflammatory disease are not likely diagnoses given the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe right-sided back pain, colicky pain radiating to the right groin, nausea, pain with urination, and costovertebral angle tenderness suggest nephrolithiasis. The urine analysis shows the presence of RBCs and absence of WBC casts, which is consistent with nephrolithiasis. Cholecystitis would present with right upper quadrant pain, while pelvic inflammatory disease would present with lower abdominal pain. Pyelonephritis would present with fever and more severe flank pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe right-sided back pain that radiates to the right groin, nausea, and pain with urination. There is costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side and the urine analysis shows RBCs and no protein or casts. These symptoms are indicative of nephrolithiasis, or a kidney stone, as the most likely diagnosis. Cholecystitis would present with pain in the right upper quadrant, while pelvic inflammatory disease would have a more diffuse lower abdominal pain. Pyelonephritis would present with fever and more severe kidney pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms of severe right-sided back pain, colicky pain radiating to the right groin, and pain with urination along with laboratory findings of hematuria and leukocyturia suggest nephrolithiasis. Cholecystitis would typically present with right upper quadrant pain and fever, while pelvic inflammatory disease may present with lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. Pyelonephritis may present with fever and flank pain, but these symptoms are typically more constant and not colicky in nature.
